repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Geothermal Development and Energy
            Pre-Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Geothermal
            Development and Energy Pre-Investment Project for Kenya was
            satisfactory. The project achieved its objectives, its
            impact on institutional development was substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was satisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, with an appropriately
            designed capacity building program, it is possible to
            improve skills to a point where an agency can operate with
            minimum long-term technical assistance. Second, identifying
            the right mix of skills required for project implementation
            and ensuring that the staff are in place prior to project
            implementation with clear roles and responsibilities is
            important for successful execution of the project. Third, a
            comprehensive mid-term review can be instrumental in
            identifying problems and taking corrective actions at a
            critical stage in project implementation. Finally, financial
            covenants need to be properly designed at the beginning,
            taking into account the existing structural constraints in
            the sector.

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Geothermal Development and Energy
            Preinvestment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The principal objective of the
            Geothermal Development and Energy Pre-Investment Project is
            to assist Kenya in preparing the necessary expansion of its
            generating capacity, and in particular the mobilization for
            a major geothermal program. The project is composed of two
            components. The first, a geothermal component, which
            consists of : (i) drilling supplies and materials for 32
            wells; (ii) procurement of a drilling rig rated for 2800
            meters; (iii) drilling infrastructure and geothermal
            scientific equipment; and (iv) 36 man-months of technical
            assistance and an engineering study. The second component is
            energy preinvestment, which consists of : (i) a feasibility
            study of hydro resources of the Miriu-Sondu basin, and an
            engineering report for the Lower Miriu weir and power
            station; (ii) comparative reconnaissance on several
            potential hydro sites; (iii) an energy pricing study; (iv) a
            study of the Kenyan LPG supply; and (v) a rural
            electrification cost minimization study.
